rev.comment: /* Background */ adding fact tag... the previous scoure only supports the sentence it follows; the source says nothing of Eddy's quote
rev.diff:
Line 8: Line 8:
The Year 2000 problem was the subject of the early book, "Computers in Crisis" by Jerome and Marilyn Murray (Petrocelli, 1984; reissued by McGraw-Hill under the title "The Year 2000 Computing Crisis" in 1996). The first recorded mention of the Year 2000 Problem on a [[Usenet]] newsgroup occurred Saturday, [[January 19]], [[1985]] by Usenet poster [[Spencer Bolles]].[http://groups.google.com/group/net.bugs/browse_thread/thread/64696a1b035aab72/e08bf2a04ec7e754?lnk=gst&q=2000&rnum=1&fwc=2].
The Year 2000 problem was the subject of the early book, "Computers in Crisis" by Jerome and Marilyn Murray (Petrocelli, 1984; reissued by McGraw-Hill under the title "The Year 2000 Computing Crisis" in 1996). The first recorded mention of the Year 2000 Problem on a [[Usenet]] newsgroup occurred Saturday, [[January 19]], [[1985]] by Usenet poster [[Spencer Bolles]].[http://groups.google.com/group/net.bugs/browse_thread/thread/64696a1b035aab72/e08bf2a04ec7e754?lnk=gst&q=2000&rnum=1&fwc=2].
â
The term was coined on [[June 12]], [[1995]] in an e-mail sent by [[David Eddy]], a Massachusetts programmer [http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/y2k/a2.html]. He later said, "People were calling it CDC (Century Date Change) and FADL (Faulty Date Logic). There were other contenders. It just came off my [[COBOL]] calloused fingertips."
+
The term was coined on [[June 12]], [[1995]] in an e-mail sent by [[David Eddy]], a Massachusetts programmer [http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/y2k/a2.html]. He later said, "People were calling it CDC (Century Date Change) and FADL (Faulty Date Logic). There were other contenders. It just came off my [[COBOL]] calloused fingertips."{{fact}}
It was speculated that computer programs could stop working or produce erroneous results because they stored years with only two digits and that the year 2000 would be represented by ''00'' and would be interpreted by software as the year [[1900]]. This would cause date comparisons to produce incorrect results. It was also thought that [[embedded systems]], making use of similar date logic, might fail and cause utilities and other crucial infrastructure to fail.
It was speculated that computer programs could stop working or produce erroneous results because they stored years with only two digits and that the year 2000 would be represented by ''00'' and would be interpreted by software as the year [[1900]]. This would cause date comparisons to produce incorrect results. It was also thought that [[embedded systems]], making use of similar date logic, might fail and cause utilities and other crucial infrastructure to fail.
